comments.commentBody:
Here is the most persuasive TV program I've seen (for a non-technical audience), in making the case that we should take AGW climate-change seriously:

A National Geographic 60-minute PBS program broadcast Wednesday, January 5, 2011 at 8:00 pm:

"MASTERS OF THE ARCTIC ICE"

Available on DVD from Amazon:

http://www.amazon.com...

Thesis: "The Arctic is the largest expanse of frozen water on the planet. All creatures that make their home there are masters of survival, superbly adapted to the Arctic ice. But climate change has begun to eat away at the ice on which these creatures depend. Two teams of researchers are racing to find out how global warming is rocking the Arctic world -- before there's nothing left but water."

The narration uses the phrase "global warming" at least a dozen times, and portrays AGW as the evil force that will, with absolute certainty, melt 100% of summer ice by the year 2100, and therefore kill off all of the seals, polar bears, etc. -- these photogenic "masters of survival".

I'm not saying I'm a huge fan of this kind of propaganda, however the DVD will be very convincing to liberals / environmentalists.

Larry G.
Seattle, WA

Story Idea -- What are season ticket holders to do if there is no CBA in place? Are owners going to be so greedy that they will collect fans money knowing that there will be no next year? Should fans refuse to pay a deposit until a CBA is in place? What is a fan supposed to do?
thank God for spring training, Just a couple of months away.

Sanchez won't be starting by mid-2012 season. Sorry, but he has played 37 nfl games already and has yet to put together 4 quarters. And with the offensive talent they had surrounding him this year? They should have had a dominating offense this season.

The real sin is that for more than four decades the NFL has only played it's ultimate game in locations that couldn't possibly have classic "football weather." The Ice Bowl in Green Bay remains one of the greatest games in the league's history. I'm sure the limo's will be able to make their way to the Meadowlands in time.

Michael Cornelius

www.onsportsandlife.com
If we left today there would be no peace in the middle east. They hate each other more than they hate us. Until the women care about the outcome, there will be no change.

"The protests rocking the Arab world this week have one thread uniting them: Al Jazeera, the Qatar-based satellite channel whose aggressive coverage has helped propel insurgent emotions from one capital to the next."

If either of the two reporters who wrote this article have read anything about the protests in Tunisia or Egypt they might be surprised to learn that most of the protesters are young, educated college students who are much better informed than the authors. They have no job and a bleak future. They are fighting for a more democratic government and a change in the status quo. Maybe you should take a lesson.

Strangely, from what I have seen. Religion has taken a back seat in the protests so far, the Muslim Brotherhood plans to participate in the Egyptian protests tomorrow but it will be the first instance of them getting involved in the current upheaval. These are students out there in the streets doing this, students who use facebook and twitter and who consume international culture. These are not reprisals directed against America or Egypt but mounting frustration over a complete lack of jobs and the omnipresence of government harassment and corruption. The man who immolated himself in Tunisia did so because he was jobless and desperate and fed up with the autocratic dictator running the place. We need to do the obvious and correct thing in this instance and support the youth. Arab dictators all over the world are aging and aging badly. If we posture ourselves against democratic revolution the islamists will win out in those countries the civilized world will suffer. But you don't have to take my word for it. Does the man in this clip appear to be an Islamist bent on destroying america or does this look like a student protester?

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FgxH93oSGn0

I don't think changes in Arab regimes will have much of an impact on the US. The State Department will have to earn their salaries to manage the new regimes for a little while. Given the history of the region, I will not be surprised to see the establishment of a new set of dictators, who may will quickly seek the support and protection of one or another powerful foreign government. Given China's energy needs, it will not be surprising to see Chinese make a play to substantially increase its influence in the Arab world.

I would agree slightly with you peterg but also say they position stories in order to grab the most attention to their network and keep the attention there just as it is in most places. Also, being the only major news agency in the region means their interpretation of events is based locally and their interpretations will usually be reflective of longer and more personal coverage.

"...whose aggressive coverage has helped propel insurgent emotions from one capital to the next."
-Interesting how they use "insurgent emotions" when the word "insurgent" is popularly used in the US to described terrorists. Forcible opposition and armed resistance is hardly how most of these protests are unfolding as a whole.

@ vijay, your generalizations are far too broad. as a muslim you should know better than to compartmentalize such a significant population of the global community into neat little stereotypes without contextualization, this is merely following suit with those that put all muslims into the box of islamists, or even dare i say it, terrorists. our communities are much more nuanced, and while yes all so-called "islamic" governments have abused the spiritual teachings of islam for political gain (a great point of argument for the separation of all forms of "church" and state no matter the religion), it is not social turmoil that we face, it is political turmoil, the social aspects being inevitable, unfortunate byproducts. what we face are despots and crooks, cronies and fascists who are all part of a global transnational network (that includes members of all faiths) of a ruling class that has a few things in mind, power, wealth and further gain. now that includes all sides of the spectrum, from the "friendly" muslims (what's so friendly about Wahhabism?) to the "enemy" muslims (too many to name here) the operative word being "power," those that supposedly speak for the vast communities that make up our billion strong population. i am not sure why you emphasize the growing population of muslims, is it because predominately christian populations are so deathly afraid of becoming outnumbered by MOSLEMS? the global population needs to be put in check in general for the sake of our collective sustainability from india to china and beyond, while places like the US need to stop using (and abusing) so much of the earth's natural resources with all its consumption.

As a Muslim, I wait for the day that Atheists rule the world so that this whole smoke screen of religion can be put aside and world leaders and the economic systems that they control can be examined more intelligently by a larger portion of the global population. It is that inherent weakness of blind faith that allows for religion to be so abused, especially within the political sphere.

How sad it is that the United States does so much to support these undemocratic, autocratic dictators in the Arab world. We didn't learn from our Iran experience where we supported to the hilt the brutal Shah of Iran. Just as we lost influence in that country, we will lose influence in the Arab world as the dictators begin to fall.

American military and foreign policy since the end of WWII has been an unmitigated disaster. We talk a good game about human rights, but we do just the opposite, whether it be in the Palestinian territories or in Latin America.

Don't for one minute believe this hypocrisy is lost on the world. In the future America will lose influence and power as countries and regions like China, Europe, India, and South America take our place. The loss of American influence and power will be well deserved.

The modern world is producing stronger communications and greater freedoms for those who have been oppressed for so long. Ironically, this is working against American favor because of brutal and reactionary American policies.

Yassir earns $1 per day when he can find work. After the government stopped providing free bread to Yassir for his wife and eight kids, Yassir demands a new government that can deliver the bread.

The US press corps reports a democratic uprising. Yassir knows nothing about democracy. Yassir knows Allah has blessed him because his wife is pregnant with a ninth child, but the government did not come across with the bread.

We have used our dictator puppets to secure our interests but the blowback began long ago. Our tragic overthrow of democratic governments in Iran and Guatemala bred immense suffering. I am still stunned that our interventions in Chile have not caused us more harm than they have. What we did in Chile was utterly discreditable, cynical, and cruel.

I do not think that most people in Islamic societies necessarily like the religious tyrants such as those who took over Iran, but we might suffer from well earned disdain with serious negative consequences. We are not in control as if we ever really were.

Years ago, my dad had a friend, a colonel from the Air Force, who had spent years working in Thailand. The friend told my father we would do much better in the world if we left people alone.  Contrition and humility are the order of the day.

Aljazera reported news about middle east as no one else did. They showed the western world truth about middle east and Asia instead of " controlled " media news chosen by " certain " false perceptions created by those who wants to shape public minds as they please.
They shook there governments and embarrassed many from the west asking them questions to expose the truth about them.

I work at a high school in rural Japan. My students are bright, cheerful, respectful and incredibly hard-working. When I ask the brightest ones what they want to be when they finish college, they all say, 'public servant.'

At first I thought they somehow all lacked imagination or ambition. But after a few years here, I think it is because they hear every day that the days of lifetime employment are over, and they want job security.

These are very smart people who will work extremely hard their entire lives in return for secure employment that they can count on to support their families and them in their old age. It is not too much to ask, but the jobs don't seem to be there.

Young Japanese do not 'create' their own jobs because this entire society is risk-averse. From the time Japanese people begin school, it is drilled into their heads that making a mistake is unacceptable, and if you do so, you should cover it up or pass the blame. 'Finding a job' has always been seen as the safe route, but as many are now seeing, that is not the safe route. This leaves them stuck, because they also don't know how to consider alternatives widely considered 'risky', such as starting a business.

I've been here 15 years, and all the while, I've seen that Japanese people would rather do nothing, like a deer caught in the headlights, than take action that could result in making a mistake.

These is the main cultural root of Japan's 20 year recession, and it is also the reason why Japan can never regain its former position. It will continue to decline until it is a hollow shell of its former self. A small minority of young Japanese who are creative risk-takers will end up leaving Japan for countries where their creativity and risk-taking is nurtured and rewardeds. But not here.

It's too bad that it's much harder for young Japanese to start their own business otherwise it could be a goldmine of new ideas and innovations for the Japanese. It's easier to start a business in the US but our young people will have to be literate first which is a tall order.

Also unchecked immigration like the US do not work so stop with the criticism of Japan about how they're coping with an aging society.

Solution: Japanese youth emigrate to the USA. These new, highly literate Americans produce tremendous economic value and help us with our own aging population. China, with no legal immigration, becomes just like Japan today by 2030-- the fastest cycle from feudalism to communism to capitalism to stagnancy in human civilization. Then we invite China's youth of tomorrow -- their best -- to become Americans too. We repeat the cycle, creating the smartest, richest, most diverse nation on Earth. Oh, wait! I forgot. The GOP hates immigrants and we can't have any. Never mind. Let's just squander another economic boom on the altar of know nothingness.

All we have to fear is fear itself.

A society with many interests creates many niches. A society with one viewpoint of what is good and desirable loses it's niche-i-ness. Prices rise for the goods designated as desirable and they either become commoditized (with streamlined mass production [less jobs]) or become impossibly expensive.

Japanese prosperity has only one place to go,downhill. They do not let their women to work so 50% of the population is virtually wasted as far as economic activity goes. They are fiercely nationalistic and hence do not want immigrants, coupled with low birth rate and long life expectancy,the working male carries a huge economic burden.So I wonder how long the aging Japanese male can hold on to economic supremacy.Arguably,not very long.

I can see it now. Cries of "America, don't let this happen to you!" Generational warfare ensues and "entitlements" for older Americans are stripped away. Of course, those entitlements were paid with blood and soul-crushing work by the retirees but why ruin a good Ayn Rand story? Look at the comments already. One bozo wants baby boomers to retire to make way for young workers. There are NO jobs! Not for anyone. Baby boomers are broke, down-sized, and deflated. Retire with what? And if they could retire, how does an unemployed baby boomer create a job by retiring? Here's a quarter. Buy yourself a clue, son necause this show is coming to a town near you too.

Let Japan figure out their problems and let us figure out ours. I'll bet they manage theirs better than we do ours. They are savers. They invest in infrustrucure. They are highly educated. Americans, not so much. And you know all that extra special American entrepreneurship? Well, it's a whole new world. Capital moves easily across oceans (the way jobs already have) and I'll bet the next apple, or the one after that, comes from somewhere in the East. Then we'll be left with nothing but hillbillies and guns here. What a prospect! I bet we'll still be singing the virtue of American exceptionalism even then.

Chris@25, without those 'bloated' entitlement and pension programs older workers will stay in their jobs longer, reducing available positions for young workers trying to get a job.  Rather than encouraging people to keep working until they're 68 or 70, we should be trying to come up with creative ways to enable more older workers to either retire or semi-retire.

They are sending the 'young' out into the world to essentially colonize other nations.  You will find many of them in Central America running the maquilladoras.  They need to be sent home.  Free trade is not working.  It is destroying nations and weakening the world.  The Japanese should be able to rebuild their national defense forces and control Asia as they were meant to do.
